items.title: Version installed becomes zipp-0.0.0 when built from source code with python 3.7.7
items.body:
When we build from zipp-3.1.0 source code, it is getting installed as zipp-0.0.0. Due to which other modules rely on zipp gets impacted. _( We dont want our build server to pull packages from internet, hence building from source code)_

```
[root@makesh-py3x zipp-3.1.0]# /mypath/python/bin/python3.7 setup.py install
running install
running bdist_egg
running egg_info
writing zipp.egg-info/PKG-INFO
writing dependency_links to zipp.egg-info/dependency_links.txt
writing requirements to zipp.egg-info/requires.txt
writing top-level names to zipp.egg-info/top_level.txt
reading manifest file 'zipp.egg-info/SOURCES.txt'
writing manifest file 'zipp.egg-info/SOURCES.txt'
installing library code to build/bdist.freebsd-8.4-RELEASE-amd64/egg
running install_lib
running build_py
copying zipp.py -> build/lib
creating build/bdist.freebsd-8.4-RELEASE-amd64/egg
copying build/lib/zipp.py -> build/bdist.freebsd-8.4-RELEASE-amd64/egg
byte-compiling build/bdist.freebsd-8.4-RELEASE-amd64/egg/zipp.py to zipp.cpython-37.pyc
creating build/bdist.freebsd-8.4-RELEASE-amd64/egg/EGG-INFO
copying zipp.egg-info/PKG-INFO -> build/bdist.freebsd-8.4-RELEASE-amd64/egg/EGG-INFO
copying zipp.egg-info/SOURCES.txt -> build/bdist.freebsd-8.4-RELEASE-amd64/egg/EGG-INFO
copying zipp.egg-info/dependency_links.txt -> build/bdist.freebsd-8.4-RELEASE-amd64/egg/EGG-INFO
copying zipp.egg-info/requires.txt -> build/bdist.freebsd-8.4-RELEASE-amd64/egg/EGG-INFO
copying zipp.egg-info/top_level.txt -> build/bdist.freebsd-8.4-RELEASE-amd64/egg/EGG-INFO

creating 'dist/zipp-0.0.0-py3.7.egg' and adding 'build/bdist.freebsd-8.4-RELEASE-amd64/egg' to it
removing 'build/bdist.freebsd-8.4-RELEASE-amd64/egg' (and everything under it)
Processing zipp-0.0.0-py3.7.egg
```

pip list gives :
```

```
Edit: Observed with zipp-2.1.0 also.

items.title: Non-ASCII character '\xe2' in file
items.body:
I got the following while running `python2.7 -m pip install -U --user pipenv` on CentOS7:

```
File "/home/users/bhundven/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zipp.py", line 153
SyntaxError: Non-ASCII character '\xe2' in file /home/users/bhundven/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zipp.py on line 154, but no encoding declared; see http://www.python.org/peps/pep-0263.html for details
```

I found that the ascii characters were added in dff39a60b729ca9dad55a41bb2a340ad8868c3a5
I was able to pin `zipp==1.1.1`, and was able to move forward: `python2.7 -m pip install -U --user "zipp==1.1.1" pipenv`

items.title: zipp 1.2.0 testing not python-2.7 compatible
items.body:
I assume that zipp-1.x is intended to still be working with python-2.7. Free free to close if that's incorrect.

When running the self tests for it, there is the following failure:
````
ImportError: Failed to import test module: test_zipp
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/pkg/lib/python2.7/unittest/loader.py", line 254, in _find_tests
    module = self._get_module_from_name(name)
  File "/usr/pkg/lib/python2.7/unittest/loader.py", line 232, in _get_module_from_name
    __import__(name)
  File "/scratch/archivers/py-zipp1/work/zipp-1.2.0/test_zipp.py", line 28, in <module>
    import jaraco.itertools
  File "/usr/pkg/lib/python2.7/site-packages/jaraco/itertools.py", line 15, in <module>
    import collections.abc
ImportError: No module named abc
````
when I look at jaraco.itertools' `setup.cfg`, I see that it's only for python >= 3.6:
https://github.com/jaraco/jaraco.itertools/blob/master/setup.cfg#L21

items.title: KeyError attempting to open a non-existent directory
items.body:
Today, I discovered if you attempt to open a non-existent directory in a zip file, a `KeyError` is emitted.

```
>>> import zipfile
>>> import io
>>> zf = zipfile.ZipFile(io.BytesIO(), 'w')
>>> zf.open('foo/')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/zipfile.py", line 1512, in open
    zinfo = self.getinfo(name)
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/zipfile.py", line 1439, in getinfo
    raise KeyError(
KeyError: "There is no item named 'foo/' in the archive"
```

That's fine, I guess, but `zipp.Path.open` should probably trap that error and replace it with a `IsADirectoryError` or `FileNotFoundError` depending on whether that name exists as a directory or not, similar to what you see from `pathlib.Path.open`.

items.title: easy_install installs zipp 3.0.0 on Python 2
items.body: When using `easy_install` from Python 2, to install zipp, it installs version 3.0.0, which is not compatible with Python 2. When using `pip` it installs the correct version for Python 2. It is possible to have the same behavior as `pip` with `easy_install`?

items.title: Improve support for streaming text with .open()
items.body: Currently, zipp.Path defers to zipfile.ZipFile.open for opening a stream to a file in the zipfile. This method does not have support for decoding to text. To improve compatibility with `pathlib.Path.open` (whose default behavior is to decode to text), zipp should honor `b` in the `mode` parameter and honor encoding parameters to `open()`.

items.title: Directories with many subdirectories are slow to iterate because of inlined set operation
items.body:
After upgrading zipp from version 2.0.1 to 2.2.0 some tests in a project I'm working on started running at ~3x the speed. The slowness came from zipp iterating the pyspark directory. When I started looking into to why, I was able to narrow it down to this commit: https://github.com/jaraco/zipp/commit/0f036c6406052426019f32c85d882e44903be89f

Reproduce by timing the following code with and without the set operation inlined:
```python
data = ["x/%s" % i for i in range(10000)]
zipp.CompleteDirs._implied_dirs(data)
```

With `set(names)` inlined for _me_ the above code took on average ~90x longer to run with one "sub directory", ~110x with 2, ~120x with 3. So I'd assume that directories with many subdirectories, especially with some nesting are slow.

Tested on:
Python 3.6.5 and 3.6.9
Zipp version: 2.1.0+

items.title: 2.2.0 will install only on  Python 3.6, not on 3.7 or 3.8
items.body:
Due to this line in `setup.cfg`:

https://github.com/jaraco/zipp/blob/v2.2.0/setup.cfg#L17

The wheel published to PyPi is limited to Python 3.6 and will not install on Python 3.7 or 3.8 (name has `py36` and nothing else in it: `zipp-2.2.0-py36-none-any.whl`):

https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/46/42/f2dd964b2a6b1921b08d661138148c1bcd3f038462a44019416f2342b618/zipp-2.2.0-py36-none-any.whl

The `[options]` say `python_version >= 3.6`, but the binary distribution setting is 3.6-only. One of these is not correct, and I suspect it's binary distribution setting. Assuming it is, the `python-tag` needs to be changed to either `python-tag=py36.py37.py38` or to `universal=1`.

items.title: incorrect interpreter specified in wheel
items.body: The wheel is generated with py3 when it should be generated with py36 as Python 3.6 is required.

items.title: joinpath() and exists() are linear-time
items.body:
The time complexity of `exists()` and `joinpath()` is linear in the number of entries in the .zip file. This is pretty unintuitive and unexpected, as the equivalent operations in pathlib are constant time. I'm assuming this is also unintended.

This leads to pathologies. For example, the search() function in importlib_metadata calls joinpath() on every entry in the zipfile, making it quadratic in the number of entries: https://gitlab.com/python-devs/importlib_metadata/blob/master/importlib_metadata/__init__.py#L440 . 

On a zipfile with ~6K entries, we're seeing it take 2-3 seconds to do a single joinpath() operation (!).

The underlying reason that `joinpath()` and `exists()` are linear time is that they call `_names()`, which computes an expanded entries list (adding implied directories to it) on the fly, every time.
It does so in order to support zipfiles that are mutating. However in the importlib_metadata use case at least, the zipfiles are read-only and this expanded entries list could be cached.

Options to fix this include:

1. Don't support mutating zipfiles. Always cache the expanded entries list.
2. Detect the case of mutating zipfiles, cache the expanded entries list in all other cases.
3. Don't worry about implied dirs. Only consider entries that are explicitly listed in the zipfile index. This may break client code expectations, I don't know enough about those to be sure.
4. For `joinpath()`, just mechanically join the argument, don't worry about normalizing trailing slashes depending on what the path actually is. Note that the join method in pathlib doesn't do any existence checking, it is perfectly reasonable to generate paths that don't exist. It always strips trailing slashes and has no opinion on whether the resulting path represents a file or a directory (because again, it may not exist at all).  Whereas here `joinpath()` has the odd behavior that what it returns changes based on whether the underlying entry exists and is a file or a dir. 

Note that option 4 doesn't solve the problem for `exists()`.

items.title: Pypi egg_info incorrect
items.body:
The `importlib-metadata` library has a dependency on the zipp module.  The zipp module in pypi appears to have incorrect egg_info as signified by the following warning when attempting to satisfy the dependency:

"Downloading https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/69/d2/daa94177e934b0b1b0780f5c856c41c248a88b2f43c046ae23afb0116ec0/zipp-2.0.1.tar.gz
  Running setup.py (path:/tmp/pip-build-CIm5mP/zipp/setup.py) egg_info for package zipp produced metadata for project name unknown. Fix your #egg=zipp fragments."

Was there a change in the egg_info from version 1.0?  Can the change be reverted?

items.title: Python 3.5 finds no matching distribution
items.body:
I cannot install zipp 2.0.0 under CPython 3.5:

```
$ python -m pip install --quiet --upgrade -r requirements.d/venv.txt
00:04
 ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement zipp==2.0.0 (from -r requirements.d/venv.txt (line 15)) (from versions: 0.1.0, 0.2.0, 0.2.1, 0.3.0, 0.3.1, 0.3.2, 0.3.3, 0.4.0, 0.5.0, 0.5.1, 0.5.2, 0.6.0, 1.0.0)
 ERROR: No matching distribution found for zipp==2.0.0 (from -r requirements.d/venv.txt (line 15))
```

Here is a public pipeline job erroring out because of that:

<https://gitlab.com/offis.energy/mosaik/mosaik.Demo_SemVer/-/jobs/408320225>

items.title: Cannot install on python since more-itertools droped Python 2.7
items.body:
more-itertools dropped python 2.7 support in version 6.0.0. 

The fix would be to fix the version to 5.0.0 when installing with python 2.

I am, unfortunately stuck with Python 2. I'll try to submit a pull request addressing the problem later today.

items.title: Dependency incompatible with Python 2.7
items.body:
This project requires more-itertools in any version.
The last version of more-itertools to be compatible with Python 2.7 is 5.0.0. 
Starting with 6.0.0 more-itertools has dropped support for Python 2.7.
Please look into this issue.
Thank you.

P.S. This issue only affects interpreters with PIP < 9.0.0 for which the python_requires argument is not implemented.

items.title: directories are both missing and duplicated
items.body: Reported in [bpo-37772](https://bugs.python.org/issue37772), the zipp.Path objects fail to show directories in otherwise empty directories and report directories containing multiple objects multiple times.

items.title: Attempting to get a parent of a dir results in the same object
items.body: In ae4be5a, I illustrate an issue I discovered where retrieving the parent of a directory results in the same object and not actually the parent.

items.title: Support zip files without directory entries
items.body: In [this investigation](https://github.com/pypa/packaging-problems/issues/212#issuecomment-487138721), I learned that some tools (wheel, and probably others) will create zip files with directory entries missing. I think zipp should support those files.

items.title: .name on a directory returns the empty string
items.body: When invoking `.name` on a zipp.Path, if that path ends with a `/` (because it's a directory), `.name` yields the empty string. It should instead return the directory name.

items.title: TypeError on Python 2.7 when using legacy floor division
items.body:
When using `zipp.Path() / str()` on Python 2.7 without `from __future__ import division`, a TypeError is raised:

`TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for /: 'Path' and 'unicode'`

items.title: TypeError when traversing with path-like object
items.body:
In [importlib_metadata!24](https://gitlab.com/python-devs/importlib_metadata/merge_requests/24), I discovered an issue that on Python 3.5, when a Pathlib object is passed as the `add` parameter for `__truediv__`, a TypeError is raised:

```
zipp.py:98: in __truediv__
    next = posixpath.join(self.at, add)
/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.5/lib/python3.5/posixpath.py:89: in join
    genericpath._check_arg_types('join', a, *p)
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

funcname = 'join', args = ('', PosixPath('a')), hasstr = True, hasbytes = False, s = PosixPath('a')

    def _check_arg_types(funcname, *args):
        hasstr = hasbytes = False
        for s in args:
            if isinstance(s, str):
                hasstr = True
            elif isinstance(s, bytes):
                hasbytes = True
            else:
                raise TypeError('%s() argument must be str or bytes, not %r' %
>                               (funcname, s.__class__.__name__)) from None
E               TypeError: join() argument must be str or bytes, not 'PosixPath'

/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.5/lib/python3.5/genericpath.py:143: TypeError
```
